Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is aimed at elucidating the early stages of folding of apomyoglobin (apoMb), an a-helical protein known to fold via a series of partially structured states. The structural and kinetic properties of the conformational changes associated with the transition from the unfolded state to an ensemble of intermediate states populated at acidic pH will be studied by combining continuous-flow fluorescence and quenched-flow H/D exchange measurements on the microsecond time scale with site-directed mutagenesis. Key residues involved in stabilizing early intermediates and transition states in folding will be identified by measuring the thermodynamic and kinetic consequences of alanine substitutions at conserved positions within the protein core. The formation of specific tertiary interactions during folding will be probed by replacing small residues at specific helix-helix docking sites by larger hydrophobic side chains, which will disrupt specific side chain contacts while maintaining non-specific hydrophobic interactions. Specific helix pairing interactions will be observed by using cysteine as an intramolecular quencher of tryptophan fluorescence. A novel quenched-flow hydrogen exchange experiment with a dead-time of 60 ms will provide complementary information on the acquisition of hydrogen-bonded structure during the initial stages of apoMb folding. The results obtained will identify critical residues and interactions (the folding nucleus) involved in directing structure formation during initial stages of folding, and will thus elucidate the sequence determinants of protein folding. The findings will provide a firm experimental framework for developing and testing theoretical and computational models of complex folding reactions involving intermediate states.

Advanced rapid mixing techniques and detection methods developed in the principal investigator's laboratory not only represent a unique resource for the protein folding community, but also benefit other areas of research, such as kinetic studies of rapid conformational changes and enzymatic reaction mechanisms. This project offers extensive opportunities for training future scientists in experimental techniques and theoretical concepts, including protein biochemistry, advanced kinetic techniques, optical and NMR spectroscopy, and the principles of protein structure and folding. Although the Fox Chase Cancer Center is not a degree-granting institution, the principal investigator has access to and will train students at all levels, including a) graduate students from the University of Pennsylvania and Temple University; b) graduate students visiting Fox Chase through a partnership with universities in Russia; c) a summer research program for undergraduate students; and (d) the Howard Hughes Medical Institutes Student Scientist Program, which places gifted students from local high schools in Fox Chase labs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Even after decades of research focusing on the mechanisms of protein folding, fundamental questions concerning the origin of kinetic barriers and the properties and kinetic roles of intermediate states remain unanswered. Do early folding events represent formation of partially structured states or compact versions of the unfolded protein ensemble? Do folding intermediates serve as productive “stepping stones” in finding the native structure or misfolded dead-end states? What are the sequence determinants for initiating and propagating folding? Is there a critical set of residues that form a “folding nucleus” necessary for crossing the main kinetic barrier in folding?

 

To address these fundamental questions, we used new experimental and conceptual approaches to explore early stages of folding of apomyoglobin (apoMb), a prototypical helical protein (Figure 1). The primary aims of this project were (1) to elucidate the folding mechanism of apoMb by rapid kinetics approaches; (2) to determine the thermodynamic and kinetic consequences of amino acid substitutions at conserved positions within the primary hydrophobic core of the protein; and (3) to monitor formation of hydrogen-bonded structure during early stages of folding by ultrafast quenched-flow H/D exchange. Our detailed kinetic analysis of wild-type apoMb on the microsecond time scale has revealed a surprisingly complex folding mechanism, including evidence for a previously unobserved partially collapsed intermediate state (Figure 2). This study paved the way for elucidating the folding dynamics of mutant proteins. A full kinetic analysis of the microsecond folding dynamics of eleven apoMb variants with amino acid substitutions throughout the hydrophobic core of the protein (Figure 1) yielded new insight into the impact of key residues on structure acquisition during each stage of folding and has led to a better understanding of the sequence determinants of apoMb protein folding. With respect to the third aim, we developed an improved methodology for quenched-flow H/D exchange measurements during early stages of protein folding, using a novel microfluidic mixing device with a dead time of less than 100 microseconds. This grant also supported a detailed rapid-kinetics study on the folding mechanism of the sheep prion protein, which implicated a transient unfolding intermediate in rendering certain polymorphic variants susceptible to formation of the pathogenic scrapie form.

The work supported by this grant has also led to important advances in rapid kinetics techniques and detection methods, including a novel microfluidic quenched-flow technique with microsecond time resolution, as well as tools for quantitative modeling of complex kinetic data. These techniques not only open new avenues for studies of early events in protein folding, but also benefit other areas of research, such as kinetic studies of rapid conformational changes and enzymatic reaction mechanisms.
